content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

A bank categorizes its customers into one of three groups based on their banking habits. A random sample of <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> customers from each group was selected, and the number of times each customer visited the bank during the past year was recorded. The following table shows the summary statistics.

Group
 <math alttext="n"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="x bar "><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="s"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

A
 <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="48"><mstyle><mrow><mn>48</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="7"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

B
 <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="51"><mstyle><mrow><mn>51</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

C
 <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="54"><mstyle><mrow><mn>54</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

The bank manager will investigate whether there is a significant difference in mean numbers of bank visits for the groups. Multiple two-sample <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests will be conducted, each at the significance level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) How many <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests will need to be conducted for the manager’s investigation? List the pairs of groups for each test.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

A bank categorizes its customers into one of three groups based on their banking habits. A random sample of <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> customers from each group was selected, and the number of times each customer visited the bank during the past year was recorded. The following table shows the summary statistics.

Group
 <math alttext="n"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="x bar "><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="s"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

A
 <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="48"><mstyle><mrow><mn>48</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="7"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

B
 <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="51"><mstyle><mrow><mn>51</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

C
 <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="54"><mstyle><mrow><mn>54</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

The bank manager will investigate whether there is a significant difference in mean numbers of bank visits for the groups. Multiple two-sample <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests will be conducted, each at the significance level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) How many <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests will need to be conducted for the manager’s investigation? List the pairs of groups for each test.

The significance level <math alttext="alpha"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>α</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of a single hypothesis test is the probability of making a Type <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error. The manager wants to know the probability of making a Type <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error for multiple <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests, not just for a single <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test. This probability is called the family error rate for Type <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error, which is also known as the family error rate.

(b) A <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test has two possible outcomes: reject or do not reject the null hypothesis. Suppose the null hypothesis is true. If the null hypothesis is rejected, the result is statistically significant, which would be a Type <math alttext="1"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> error; if the null hypothesis is not rejected, the result is not statistically significant, which would not be a Type <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> error. Let <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent a statistically significant result, and let <math alttext="N"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent a result that is not statistically significant.

(i) If <math alttext="the probability of S equals 0.05"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the value of <math alttext="the probability of N"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

The bank manager knows that the investigation will involve conducting multiple two-sample <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests. The manager begins the investigation by considering two different <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests as independent, successive trials. The possible outcomes of the trials, <math alttext="N"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, are shown in the following tree diagram.

(ii) The family error rate is the probability of obtaining a significant result for at least one of the <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests conducted, under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true. Use the tree diagram to determine the family error rate for two <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests, each conducted at a level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show your work.

(c) Determine the family error rate for the number of <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests identified in part (a), each conducted at a level of <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show your work.

(d) The manager wants the family error rate to be close to <math alttext="0.05"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Suggest a single significance level <math alttext="alpha"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that could be used for all of the individual <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-tests that will bring the family error rate close to <math alttext="0.05"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show work to support your suggested level.

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Identify key and relevant information to answer a question or solve a problem.
